cards.title: Tour de France gallery / Leader of the pack

item.title: Tour de France: stage four
item.trailText: The best photos from stage four, which took the riders from Seraing to Cambrai, a 223.5km stage that included several section of cobbles.Tony Martin powered home from 2km out to grab the yellow jersey and stage victory, but Chris Froome maintained the lead over his main GC rivals
item.standFirst:
The best photos from stage four, which took the riders from Seraing to Cambrai, and into France for the first time, on a 223.5km stage that included several demanding sections of cobbles.

Tony Martin powered home from 2km out to grab a stage win and the yellow jersey after narrowly missing out on each stage so far, but Chris Froome maintained his lead over his main general classification rivals

item.title: Wimbledon 2015: day eight
item.trailText: Guardian photographer Tom Jenkins brings you his best images from today’s play at SW19 with Novak Djokovic, Serena Williams and Maria Sharapova all in action
item.standFirst: Guardian photographer Tom Jenkins brings you his best images from today’s play at SW19 with Novak Djokovic, Serena Williams and Maria Sharapova all in action

displayImages.caption: Novak Djokovic of Serbia hits a return against Kevin Anderson of South Africa. The two players resumed this afternoon after being suspended at two sets all on Monday evening.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Novak Djokovic of Serbia hits a return against Kevin Anderson of South Africa. The two players resumed this afternoon after being suspended at two sets all on Monday evening.

displayImages.caption: Dark clouds build over No1 court, as the rain prepares to make an unwelcome return to SW19.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Dark clouds build over No1 court, as the rain prepares to make an unwelcome return to SW19.

displayImages.caption: The covers are prepared...
displayImages.cleanCaption: The covers are prepared...

displayImages.caption: ...and rain stops play before a ball is struck.
displayImages.cleanCaption: ...and rain stops play before a ball is struck.

displayImages.caption: Djokovic looks to the skies as the umbrellas go up.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Djokovic looks to the skies as the umbrellas go up.

displayImages.caption: When play did get underway, Djokovic clinched the deciding set 7-5 to reach the quarter-finals.
displayImages.cleanCaption: When play did get underway, Djokovic clinched the deciding set 7-5 to reach the quarter-finals.

displayImages.caption: Djokovic, who fought back from two sets down to fo through, will play US Open champion Marin Cilic in the quarter-finals.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Djokovic, who fought back from two sets down to fo through, will play US Open champion Marin Cilic in the quarter-finals.

displayImages.caption: Djokovic acknowledges the crowd after beating Anderson 6-7, 6-7, 6-1, 6-4, 6-4.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Djokovic acknowledges the crowd after beating Anderson 6-7, 6-7, 6-1, 6-4, 6-4.

displayImages.caption: Djokovic is congratulated by the South African No14 seed, who can reflect on a solid grass court season after also reaching the Queen’s Club final.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Djokovic is congratulated by the South African No14 seed, who can reflect on a solid grass court season after also reaching the Queen’s Club final.

displayImages.caption: Great Britain’s Anna Brogan plays a backhand in her girls’ singles match against Katarina Zavatska. Brogan won the second round match 6-1, 6-3.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Great Britain’s Anna Brogan plays a backhand in her girls’ singles match against Katarina Zavatska. Brogan won the second round match 6-1, 6-3.

displayImages.caption: Tuesday was women’s quarter-final day – here we see Maria Sharapova in action against Coco Vandeweghe of the USA.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Tuesday was women’s quarter-final day – here we see Maria Sharapova in action against Coco Vandeweghe of the USA.

displayImages.caption: Sharapova unleashes a double backhand return on her way to taking the first set 6-3.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Sharapova unleashes a double backhand return on her way to taking the first set 6-3.

displayImages.caption: Sharapova stretches for a forehand as she digs in for a 6-3, 6-7, 6-2 win over world No47 Vandeweghe.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Sharapova stretches for a forehand as she digs in for a 6-3, 6-7, 6-2 win over world No47 Vandeweghe.

displayImages.caption: Sharapova celebrates her three-set victory – but will she be facing old foe Serena Williams in the semi-finals?
displayImages.cleanCaption: Sharapova celebrates her three-set victory – but will she be facing old foe Serena Williams in the semi-finals?

displayImages.caption: Serena Williams serves in her match with Victoria Azarenka on Centre Court
displayImages.cleanCaption: Serena Williams serves in her match with Victoria Azarenka on Centre Court

displayImages.caption: Azarenka has slipped down the world rankings, but the No23 seed comes out swinging, and takes the first set 6-3
displayImages.cleanCaption: Azarenka has slipped down the world rankings, but the No23 seed comes out swinging, and takes the first set 6-3

displayImages.caption: Williams returns with a double forehand as she tries to fight her way back into the match.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Williams returns with a double forehand as she tries to fight her way back into the match.

displayImages.caption: Azarenka cannot keep her strong start going, and Williams takes the second set 6-2.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Azarenka cannot keep her strong start going, and Williams takes the second set 6-2.

displayImages.caption: Perfect timing as we see the ball flat against Williams’ racket, a split second before another forehand is unleashed.
displayImages.altText: The ball is compressed flat as Williams returns
displayImages.cleanCaption: Perfect timing as we see the ball flat against Williams’ racket, a split second before another forehand is unleashed.

displayImages.caption: Azarenka enjoys herself out on Centre Court as the match goes to a decider.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Azarenka enjoys herself out on Centre Court as the match goes to a decider.

displayImages.caption: Williams proved too strong for her Belarusian opponent, winning through 3-6, 6-2, 6-3.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Williams proved too strong for her Belarusian opponent, winning through 3-6, 6-2, 6-3.

displayImages.caption: Serena Williams celebrates another hard-fought Centre Court victory. She will now play Maria Sharapova in the last four, with Agniesza Radwanska and Garbine Muguruza meeting in the second semi-final.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Serena Williams celebrates another hard-fought Centre Court victory. She will now play Maria Sharapova in the last four, with Agniesza Radwanska and Garbine Muguruza meeting in the second semi-final.

item.title: Sport picture of the day: close but no cigar
item.trailText: Craig Overton of Somerset has a lucky escape as Matthew Hobden of Sussex fails to hold onto a diving catch at mid off from the bowling of Oliver Robinson, during day three of the LV County Championship match between Somerset and Sussex
item.standFirst: Craig Overton of Somerset has a lucky escape as Matthew Hobden of Sussex fails to hold onto a diving catch at mid off during day three of the LV County Championship match between Somerset and Sussex. Overton went on to make 53 not out as Somerset made 274 in their first innings

item.title: Australia's Ashes squad
item.trailText: Profiles and pictures of the players Australia hope will bring home the Ashes this summer
item.standFirst:
Profiles and pictures of the players Australia hope will bring home the Ashes this summer

  • View England’s squad here

displayImages.caption:
Michael Clarke
Age 34
Caps 110
Right-handed bat, captain
Previous Ashes 2005, 2006-07, 2009, 2010-11, 2013, 2013-14
Has polished his technique as his career has progressed, adding consistency to the quality he displayed in scoring 151 on his debut against India in Bangalore in 2004. He had an incredible year in 2012, when he posted scores of 210, 230, 259* and 329* and averaged 106.33 across 18 innings, and has become increasingly respected with experience, even if – as shown in his infamous arm-breaking pledge to James Anderson in the last Ashes series - he retains a fiery edge. Photograph: Ryan Pierse/Getty Images
displayImages.altText:
Michael Clarke
Age 34
Caps 110
Right-handed bat, captain
Previous Ashes 2005, 2006-07, 2009, 2010-11, 2013, 2013-14
Has polished his technique as his career has progressed, adding consistency to the quality he displayed in scoring 151 on his debut against India in Bangalore in 2004. He had an incredible year in 2012, when he posted scores of 210, 230, 259* and 329* and averaged 106.33 across 18 innings, and has become increasingly respected with experience, even if – as shown in his infamous arm-breaking pledge to James Anderson in the last Ashes series - he retains a fiery edge.
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Michael Clarke
Age 34
Caps 110
Right-handed bat, captain
Previous Ashes 2005, 2006-07, 2009, 2010-11, 2013, 2013-14
Has polished his technique as his career has progressed, adding consistency to the quality he displayed in scoring 151 on his debut against India in Bangalore in 2004. He had an incredible year in 2012, when he posted scores of 210, 230, 259* and 329* and averaged 106.33 across 18 innings, and has become increasingly respected with experience, even if – as shown in his infamous arm-breaking pledge to James Anderson in the last Ashes series - he retains a fiery edge.

displayImages.caption:
Steven Smith
Age 26
Caps 28
Right-handed bat, vice-captain
Previous Ashes 2010-11, 2013, 2013-14

Originally called into the team as a spinner who could bat a bit, Smith now bowls infrequently, and is ranked as the best Test batsman in the world. His form is formidable: in 13 Test innings since his last duck he has scored five centuries – among them 199 against West Indies and 192 against India in Melbourne; he has been out as many times in the 190s than in the 90s – and three half-centuries, a 97 among them. In 21 innings since the end of the last Ashes series he averages a remarkable 93.43. Photograph: Brendon Thorne/Getty Images

Steven Smith
Age 26
Caps 28
Right-handed bat, vice-captain
Previous Ashes 2010-11, 2013, 2013-14

Originally called into the team as a spinner who could bat a bit, Smith now bowls infrequently, and is ranked as the best Test batsman in the world. His form is formidable: in 13 Test innings since his last duck he has scored five centuries – among them 199 against West Indies and 192 against India in Melbourne; he has been out as many times in the 190s than in the 90s – and three half-centuries, a 97 among them. In 21 innings since the end of the last Ashes series he averages a remarkable 93.43.

Previous Ashes 2010-11, 2013, 2013-14

His form is formidable: in 13 Test innings since his last duck he has scored five centuries – among them 199 against West Indies and 192 against India in Melbourne; he has been out as many times in the 190s than in the 90s – and three half-centuries, a 97 among them. In 21 innings since the end of the last Ashes series he averages a remarkable 93.43.

displayImages.caption:
Fawad Ahmed
Age 33
Caps 0
Legspinner
Previous Ashes n/a
Born in Pakistan, Ahmed sought asylum in Australia but was on the verge of deportation when the then immigration minister personally intervened in 2012. He was granted full citizenship in 2013, making his Twenty20 debut for his adopted country in England that August. He has not played for Australia since they left the UK the following month, but has more recently enjoyed an excellent domestic season for Victoria, culminating in him taking eight wickets as they beat Western Australia in the Sheffield Shield final. Photograph: Julian Herbert/Getty Images
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Fawad Ahmed
Age 33
Caps 0
Legspinner
Previous Ashes n/a
Born in Pakistan, Ahmed sought asylum in Australia but was on the verge of deportation when the then immigration minister personally intervened in 2012. He was granted full citizenship in 2013, making his Twenty20 debut for his adopted country in England that August. He has not played for Australia since they left the UK the following month, but has more recently enjoyed an excellent domestic season for Victoria, culminating in him taking eight wickets as they beat Western Australia in the Sheffield Shield final.

displayImages.caption:
Pat Cummins
Age 22
Caps 1
Right-arm bowler
Previous Ashes n/a

A late call-up to replace Ryan Harris, Cummins’ one Test came nearly four years ago in South Africa, when he took seven wickets and was named man of the match. He has been severely affected by injury and has not played a first-class game for more than two years, but now insists he hasn’t “had to think about any niggles or anything for two years” and is “ready to go”. Cummins offers genuine pace, but given his lack of competitive cricket and recent arrival it would be a surprise if he saw much action outside the nets during the Ashes. Photograph: Themba Hadebe/AP

displayImages.caption:
Brad Haddin
Age 37
Caps 65
Right-handed bat, wicketkeeper
Previous Ashes 2009, 2010-11, 2013, 2013-14
A thorn in England’s side during the most recent Ashes series in Australia, when his eight innings included five half-centuries and a ton. A reliable and hostile presence behind the stumps – occasionally too hostile, being criticised for his sledging of New Zealand batsmen during this year’s World Cup final, after which he insisted that “they deserved it” for being “nice” and that he would under no circumstances be stemming his tide of invective. England can expect more of the same this summer. Photograph: Ryan Pierse/Getty Images

displayImages.caption:
Josh Hazlewood
Age 24
Caps 5
Right-arm bowler
Previous Ashes n/a

At 17 he became the youngest bowler to play for New South Wales, and at 19 the youngest to play a one-day international for Australia. The 6ft 4in Hazlewood is now living up to his early promise: he was man of the series in Australia’s recent 2-0 win in West Indies and has continued to impress in the early matches of this tour (even if Essex’s Jess Ryder hit him for 27 off one over in Chelmsford). Frequently compared with Glenn McGrath, to his evident pleasure. Photograph: Robyn Beck/AFP/Getty Images

Left-arm fast bowler
Previous Ashes 2009, 2010-11, 2013-14

In his first two Ashes series Johnson went for on average four runs an over, taking 20 wickets in 2009, when he was very far from his best, and 15 in four matches in 2010-11. In the last he went for 2.74 runs an over, and took 37 wickets, as he terrorised England’s batsman into panic and disarray. He has managed largely to sustain that form since, and is also an occasionally inspired batsman, with a high score of 123* against South Africa in 2009 and 10 half-centuries also to his name. Photograph: Sarah Ansell/Rex Shutterstock

displayImages.caption:
Nathan Lyon
Age 27
Caps 41
Right-arm offspin
Previous Ashes 2013, 2013-14

Lyon has made a famous and improbable rise from the Adelaide Oval groundstaff to Australia’s Test XI, his ability having been spotted bowling in the nets. He watched England win convincingly in Adelaide in 2010 while “sitting on the roller and preparing to pull the covers on”; when England next visited three years later he was playing against them. He made his Test debut in 2011, taking the wicket of Kumar Sangakkara with his first ever delivery on his way to a five-for. Photograph: Nick Potts/PA

displayImages.caption:
Mitchell Marsh
Age 23
Caps 4
Right-handed bat, right-arm medium
Previous Ashes n/a

One of three Mitchells in the squad (Mitchell is currently Australia’s 83rd most popular boys’ name, so it’s punching well above its weight) and the youngest member of Australia’s Dads’ Army at 23. Marsh made his state debut at 17 and his first appearances for Australia in both Twenty20 and one-day cricket in the week before he turned 20. While in the team for his batting he is also an economical bowler, though he has so far been rewarded with just one Test wicket, from 61 overs. Photograph: James Marsh/BPI/REX Shutterstock/James Marsh/BPI/REX Shutterstock

Shaun Marsh
Age 31
Caps 14
Left-handed bat
Previous Ashes n/a

Mitchell’s big brother – their father is the former Australia opener Geoff – made his debut in Sri Lanka in 2011, scoring 141 in his first Test innings and 81 in his second, but there has been only one century and three half-centuries in nearly four years since, and in all since his debut he has played in 14 of Australia’s 44 Tests, with his longest run in the team being the five consecutive games that he hopes to extend to six in Cardiff. Photograph: Nigel French/PA

displayImages.caption:
Peter Nevill
Age 29
Caps 0
Right-handed bat, wicketkeeper
Previous Ashes n/a

Before this year Nevill’s international experience had amounted to kicking his heels for one tour of West Indies in 2012, but his excellent recent form with bat and gloves for New South Wales has propelled him back into the reckoning. In the Sheffield Shield he took 29 catches and scored 764 runs – he now has a first-class batting average of 44.29. Haddin, an occasional team-mate at NSW, is “a massive influence”, and Nevill looks well placed to take over the gloves when the 37-year-old incumbent takes his off for good. Photograph: Nick Potts/PA

displayImages.caption:
Chris Rogers
Age 37
Caps 20
Left-handed bat
Previous Ashes 2013, 2013-14

The oldest member of Australia’s squad made his debut back in 2008, but after scoring four and 15 against India in Perth it was more than five years before he got another chance, in the 2013 Ashes (10 of his first 11 Test appearances were against England). His claim then was enhanced by his experience in England – he has played for Derbyshire, Leicestershire, Middlesex and Northamptonshire – but he has proved his international pedigree thereafter, and his last six Test innings have all brought half-centuries. Photograph: Paul Kane/Getty Images

displayImages.caption:
Peter Siddle
Age 30
Caps 56
Right-arm bowler
Previous Ashes 2009, 2010-11, 2013, 2013-14

The ninth and latest man to take an Ashes hat-trick – on the first day of the 2010-11 series, which happened to fall on his 26th birthday – the vegan, banana-chomping (he has a 20-a-day habit) former competitive wood-chopper is a reliably hostile bowler. He has not played a limited-overs international since 2010 but has remained a constant presence in the Test squad, even if his appearances have dried up a litte of late. Photograph: Anthony Devlin/PA

displayImages.caption:
Mitchell Starc
Age 25
Caps 17
Left-arm bowler
Previous Ashes 2013

Starc ended this year’s World Cup, in which he was named player of the tournament, as the world’s top-ranked bowler in one-day internationals. His performances with the white ball have finally earned him a consistent place in the Test team – he had played just 39.5% of Australia’s Tests between his debut in 2011 and the World Cup, as he flitted in and out of the side. Tall and reliably capable of swinging the ball, no less an authority than Wasim Akram recently said that “to me it looks like he’s there now”. Photograph: Cameron Spencer/Getty Images

Adam Voges
Age 35
Caps 2
Right-handed bat
Previous Ashes n/a

Voges admitted there was “every possibility” that he would never play for his country again after pulling out of a tour to South Africa in 2009 in order to attend his own wedding, but fought his way back into the ODI team and received a surprise call-up for this series – frustrating Middlesex, where he was supposed to spend the summer – after being named player of the year in the Sheffield Shield. He made his Test debut in the recent two-match tour of West Indies, scoring 130* in his first innings. Photograph: Ryan Pierse/Getty Images

displayImages.caption:
Shane Watson
Age 34
Caps 58
Right-handed bat, right-arm bowler
Previous Ashes 2009, 2010-11, 2013, 2013-14

An all-rounder whose batting remains his best weapon, he made a sudden improvement when moved up the order to open in the middle of the 2009 Ashes, and over the next two years averaged an impressive 49.88. Since then he has been less reliable, averaging a shade over 30. He has scored two Test centuries in the last four years and slipped back down the order to No6, while also becoming less essential with the ball – he contributed just 16 overs and one wicket to the recent West Indies series. Photograph: Mark Kolbe/Getty Images

displayImages.caption:
David Warner
Age 28
Caps 38
Left-handed bat
Previous Ashes 2013, 2013-14

Aggressive with bat, mouth and occasionally with fist, Warner remains most famous in England for a fight over a fancy dress wig with England’s Joe Root in a Birmingham bar two years ago. Dropped in the aftermath, he recovered to muscle his way back into the team before the end of that series, and averaged a shade over 58 when Australia reclaimed the Ashes in 2013-14. Now an important cog in Australia’s engine in all forms of the game. Photograph: Cameron Spencer/Getty Images

image.caption:
Michael Clarke
Age 34
Caps 110
Right-handed bat, captain
Previous Ashes 2005, 2006-07, 2009, 2010-11, 2013, 2013-14
Has polished his technique as his career has progressed, adding consistency to the quality he displayed in scoring 151 on his debut against India in Bangalore in 2004. He had an incredible year in 2012, when he posted scores of 210, 230, 259* and 329* and averaged 106.33 across 18 innings, and has become increasingly respected with experience, even if – as shown in his infamous arm-breaking pledge to James Anderson in the last Ashes series - he retains a fiery edge. Photograph: Ryan Pierse/Getty Images

image.caption:
Steven Smith
Age 26
Caps 28
Right-handed bat, vice-captain
Previous Ashes 2010-11, 2013, 2013-14

Originally called into the team as a spinner who could bat a bit, Smith now bowls infrequently, and is ranked as the best Test batsman in the world. His form is formidable: in 13 Test innings since his last duck he has scored five centuries – among them 199 against West Indies and 192 against India in Melbourne; he has been out as many times in the 190s than in the 90s – and three half-centuries, a 97 among them. In 21 innings since the end of the last Ashes series he averages a remarkable 93.43. Photograph: Brendon Thorne/Getty Images

image.caption:
Fawad Ahmed
Age 33
Caps 0
Legspinner
Previous Ashes n/a
Born in Pakistan, Ahmed sought asylum in Australia but was on the verge of deportation when the then immigration minister personally intervened in 2012. He was granted full citizenship in 2013, making his Twenty20 debut for his adopted country in England that August. He has not played for Australia since they left the UK the following month, but has more recently enjoyed an excellent domestic season for Victoria, culminating in him taking eight wickets as they beat Western Australia in the Sheffield Shield final. Photograph: Julian Herbert/Getty Images

image.caption:
Pat Cummins
Age 22
Caps 1
Right-arm bowler
Previous Ashes n/a

A late call-up to replace Ryan Harris, Cummins’ one Test came nearly four years ago in South Africa, when he took seven wickets and was named man of the match. He has been severely affected by injury and has not played a first-class game for more than two years, but now insists he hasn’t “had to think about any niggles or anything for two years” and is “ready to go”. Cummins offers genuine pace, but given his lack of competitive cricket and recent arrival it would be a surprise if he saw much action outside the nets during the Ashes. Photograph: Themba Hadebe/AP

image.caption:
Brad Haddin
Age 37
Caps 65
Right-handed bat, wicketkeeper
Previous Ashes 2009, 2010-11, 2013, 2013-14
A thorn in England’s side during the most recent Ashes series in Australia, when his eight innings included five half-centuries and a ton. A reliable and hostile presence behind the stumps – occasionally too hostile, being criticised for his sledging of New Zealand batsmen during this year’s World Cup final, after which he insisted that “they deserved it” for being “nice” and that he would under no circumstances be stemming his tide of invective. England can expect more of the same this summer. Photograph: Ryan Pierse/Getty Images

Marsh made his state debut at 17 and his first appearances for Australia in both Twenty20 and one-day cricket in the week before he turned 20. While in the team for his batting he is also an economical bowler, though he has so far been rewarded with just one Test wicket, from 61 overs.

Before this year Nevill’s international experience had amounted to kicking his heels for one tour of West Indies in 2012, but his excellent recent form with bat and gloves for New South Wales has propelled him back into the reckoning. In the Sheffield Shield he took 29 catches and scored 764 runs – he now has a first-class batting average of 44.29. Haddin, an occasional team-mate at NSW, is “a massive influence”, and Nevill looks well placed to take over the gloves when the 37-year-old incumbent takes his off for good. Photograph: Nick Potts/PA

image.caption:
Chris Rogers
Age 37
Caps 20
Left-handed bat
Previous Ashes 2013, 2013-14

The oldest member of Australia’s squad made his debut back in 2008, but after scoring four and 15 against India in Perth it was more than five years before he got another chance, in the 2013 Ashes (10 of his first 11 Test appearances were against England). His claim then was enhanced by his experience in England – he has played for Derbyshire, Leicestershire, Middlesex and Northamptonshire – but he has proved his international pedigree thereafter, and his last six Test innings have all brought half-centuries. Photograph: Paul Kane/Getty Images

Peter Siddle
Age 30
Caps 56
Right-arm bowler
Previous Ashes 2009, 2010-11, 2013, 2013-14

The ninth and latest man to take an Ashes hat-trick – on the first day of the 2010-11 series, which happened to fall on his 26th birthday – the vegan, banana-chomping (he has a 20-a-day habit) former competitive wood-chopper is a reliably hostile bowler. He has not played a limited-overs international since 2010 but has remained a constant presence in the Test squad, even if his appearances have dried up a litte of late. Photograph: Anthony Devlin/PA

image.caption:
Mitchell Starc
Age 25
Caps 17
Left-arm bowler
Previous Ashes 2013

Starc ended this year’s World Cup, in which he was named player of the tournament, as the world’s top-ranked bowler in one-day internationals. His performances with the white ball have finally earned him a consistent place in the Test team – he had played just 39.5% of Australia’s Tests between his debut in 2011 and the World Cup, as he flitted in and out of the side. Tall and reliably capable of swinging the ball, no less an authority than Wasim Akram recently said that “to me it looks like he’s there now”. Photograph: Cameron Spencer/Getty Images

image.caption:
Adam Voges
Age 35
Caps 2
Right-handed bat
Previous Ashes n/a

Voges admitted there was “every possibility” that he would never play for his country again after pulling out of a tour to South Africa in 2009 in order to attend his own wedding, but fought his way back into the ODI team and received a surprise call-up for this series – frustrating Middlesex, where he was supposed to spend the summer – after being named player of the year in the Sheffield Shield. He made his Test debut in the recent two-match tour of West Indies, scoring 130* in his first innings. Photograph: Ryan Pierse/Getty Images

image.caption:
Shane Watson
Age 34
Caps 58
Right-handed bat, right-arm bowler
Previous Ashes 2009, 2010-11, 2013, 2013-14

An all-rounder whose batting remains his best weapon, he made a sudden improvement when moved up the order to open in the middle of the 2009 Ashes, and over the next two years averaged an impressive 49.88. Since then he has been less reliable, averaging a shade over 30. He has scored two Test centuries in the last four years and slipped back down the order to No6, while also becoming less essential with the ball – he contributed just 16 overs and one wicket to the recent West Indies series. Photograph: Mark Kolbe/Getty Images

image.caption:
David Warner
Age 28
Caps 38
Left-handed bat
Previous Ashes 2013, 2013-14

Aggressive with bat, mouth and occasionally with fist, Warner remains most famous in England for a fight over a fancy dress wig with England’s Joe Root in a Birmingham bar two years ago. Dropped in the aftermath, he recovered to muscle his way back into the team before the end of that series, and averaged a shade over 58 when Australia reclaimed the Ashes in 2013-14. Now an important cog in Australia’s engine in all forms of the game. Photograph: Cameron Spencer/Getty Images
